Furniture.title: Furniture
Furniture.description: Represents a furniture item listed in the FurniFind app.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Furniture entity.

name.description: The name of the furniture item.

description.description: A detailed description of the furniture item.

price.description: The price of the furniture item.

imageUrl.description: URL of the furniture item's image.

contactInfo.description: Contact information for the seller of the furniture item.

condition.description: Condition of the furniture item (e.g., new, used, refurbished).

definition.description: Stores furniture items owned by a specific user. Access is restricted to the owner (userId).

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier of the user who owns the furniture item.

params.name: furnitureId
params.description: The unique identifier of the furniture item.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to securely manage furniture listings, focusing on ownership and clear authorization. Each user has a dedicated collection for their furniture listings, ensuring private access by default. This approach leverages path-based ownership, simplifying security rules and eliminating the need for complex authorization logic. 

**Authorization Independence:** Authorization is achieved through path-based ownership, eliminating `get()` calls in security rules. Each furniture item is stored under `/users/{userId}/furniture/{furnitureId}`, so the security rules can simply check if `request.auth.uid == userId`.

**QAPs (Rules are not Filters):** The structure enables secure `list` operations. A user can only list furniture items in their own `/users/{userId}/furniture` collection. To allow listing of all furniture (e.g. for a global search), a separate collection (e.g. `/public_furniture`) would be required with denormalized data, and its own security rules.

This design enforces clear ownership invariants, supports atomic operations (transactions/batches), and promotes ease of debugging.
